Notes on Value: Choice edible; often found in grassy areas, closely related to the button mushroom. Caution: Easily confused with deadly Amanita species (must check for dark spores and lack of volva).
Choice edible; larger than the Meadow Mushroom, with a distinctive anise-like scent.
Good edible; known for its delicate anise scent, found in woodlands and urban areas.
Choice edible; valued for its mild, earthy, and nutty flavor; widely cultivated (Note: This species is now often classified under Cyclocybe, but is historically well-known as Agrocybe).
Choice edible; firm texture, excellent flavor when young; popular in Scandinavian cuisine.
Edible when young; often bitter when mature but can be excellent when mild.
Non-edible; too tough/bitter for consumption, though a distinctive bracket fungus.
Not foraged; a plant pathogenic oomycete (water mold), not a true fungus, causing white blister diseases on vegetables.
Highly prized edible; rich, nutty flavor; excellent for drying.
Choice edible with a mild, earthy flavor; highly valued in parts of Europe.
Choice edible when young (flesh must be pure white); very large size makes it a high-yield forage.
Highly prized edible; fruity aroma, peppery flavor; excellent market value.
Edible, but typically used as a spicy seasoning when dried and powdered.
Good edible (caution: some people have gastric upset; requires confident ID). Must avoid the toxic, green-spored C. molybdites.
Edible with a mild, pleasant flavor; often overlooked.
Edible when young; mild, nutty flavor and a firm texture.
Choice edible with a distinctive mealy odor and flavor (caution: many poisonous look-alikes).
Choice edible when young (gills must be white); must be cooked quickly as it autodigests.
Highly prized edible; deep, smoky, complex flavor; excellent for drying.
Choice edible with a mild, earthy, and nutty flavor; widely cultivated.
Edible; often eaten raw in salads or slow-cooked; distinctive meaty appearance.
Good edible; winter mushroom; distinctive velvet stem (cultivated versions look different).
Valuable non-edible; prized in traditional medicine for its health benefits (typically dried for tea/tincture).
Highly prized edible; meaty texture and rich flavor; found at the base of trees, often oaks.
Choice edible; unique seafood-like flavor; also valued for medicinal properties.
Choice edible; firm texture, mild flavor, easily identified by teeth instead of gills/pores.
Edible; often found on elm trees; a good, firm-textured mushroom.
Good edible; widely foraged; less prized than porcini but often more abundant.
Edible; distinctively colored orange milk (latex); highly valued in Mediterranean countries.
Good edible (must be young); often used as a poultry substitute in cooking; grows on wood.
Highly prized edible; woody aroma and rich flavor; wild foraging is possible but it is mainly cultivated.
Good edible; distinctive lavender/purple color; late-season mushroom.
Edible when young (flesh must be pure white); common and easy to identify when sliced.
Choice edible; large, striking mushroom; known for being breaded and fried.
Good edible; excellent for drying as it retains flavor after being rehydrated.
Edible when young; can be tough but has a rich, earthy flavor; stains black when bruised.
Good edible; mild flavor, easy to identify; common on wood; one of the most widely cultivated.
Edible when young (before it toughens); mild, melon-like scent when fresh.
Edible (many coral fungi are not); mild flavor and distinctive shape (caution is needed as many coral fungi are either toxic or purgative).
Choice edible; distinctive cracked cap; mild, nutty flavor.
Choice edible; unique, frilly appearance; nutty flavor and excellent texture.
Edible (must peel cap skin); often common and abundant, a good bulk edible.
Valuable non-edible; prized for medicinal use (typically dried for tea/tincture); very common.
Edible but bland; distinctively gelatinous texture; often used for texture in Asian cuisine.
Highly prized edible; cinnamon-spicy aroma; commands a high market price.
Edible; common small bolete; mild flavor.
